title: William Dinwiddie
text:
William Dinwiddie (August 23, 1867 – June 17, 1934) was an American journalist, <a href="war%20photographer">war photographer</a>, writer and colonial administrator in the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>. He was born in <a href="Charlottesville%2C%20Virginia">Charlottesville, Virginia</a>.
Early life.
Dinwiddie took some courses at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a> (1881–1883); and then he worked as a customs inspector in Corpus Christi, Texas (1883–1886). He worked for the <a href="Bureau%20of%20American%20Ethnology">Bureau of American Ethnology</a> (1886–1895); and then he decided to change careers, becoming a foreign correspondent and photographer.
War correspondent.
Dinwiddie was a journalist and a war photographer for "<a href="Harper%27s%20Weekly">Harper's Weekly</a>" during the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a>, assigned to report and photograph the American campaigns in Cuba and Puerto Rico.
He was a <a href="war%20correspondent">war correspondent</a> for the "<a href="New%20York%20Herald">New York Herald</a>" during the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a> (1904–1905).
Personal life.
William Dinwiddie was twice married. In 1891 he married Mary E Towers, daughter of Chatham Moore Towers and Sallie Lewis Nuckolls. They were the parents of two children: Dorothy and Redfield Towers Dinwiddie. In 1901 he married Caroline Miller Brooke, daughter of William S Brooke and Mary Shoemaker Hallowell.
